titleInfo.title: Mechanism by Which Zika Virus Induces Replication Fork Stalling and Cell Cycle Arrest

mods:mods.abstract: Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus in the family Flaviviridae. Since being isolated from a rhesus macaque monkey in the Zika Forest of Uganda in 1947, only sporadic cases had been reported in Africa and Asia until 2007 when an epidemic occurred in Micronesia. A larger outbreak occurred in French Polynesia in 2013, from which a suspected link to an increased rate of Guillain-Barr√© syndrome was reported. The more recent 2015-16 ZIKV outbreak in the Americas saw the virus spread to over 70 different countries and a concurrent increase in microcephaly in babies born to infected mothers. Since ZIKV is linked to human neurological defects, the mechanisms behind its pathogenesis remain unclear. ZIKV infection in human neural progenitors triggers DNA damage and activates the ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM)/Chk2 DNA damage response (DDR) signaling pathway while simultaneously suppressing the ATM and Rad3-related kinase (ATR)/Chk1 signaling pathway, leading to cell cycle arrest which can retard brain development. During S phase, a potential collision between transcription and replication machineries makes transcription a major source of DNA replication stress. When the nascent RNA strand is inappropriately base-paired with the DNA template strand, leaving the non-template strand as single-strand DNA (ssDNA), a three-stranded DNA-RNA hybrid structure called an R-loop is formed which can interfere with replication fork progress if not resolved properly. Here we link the ZIKV-induced S phase arrest to replication fork stalling and R-loop induction. DRIP-seq revealed that ZIKV infection triggers the induction of R-loops in specific sites and the vast majority of these sites are present in the interferon-induced genes (ISGs). Bru-seq results further indicate that nascent ISGs transcripts are prone to R-loop induction upon infection. IFNAR1 KO reduced DNA damage response and S phase arrest, demonstrating a heretofore unknown role of IFN signaling in R-loop induction. Finally, overexpression of RNaseH1 partially relieved ZIKV-mediated cell cycle arrest. These data suggest that unscheduled expression of these ISGs, such as in the case of an infection, alters R-loop homeostasis and perturbs replication fork progression, leading to fork stalling and eventually DNA damage. Our study reveals a previously unknown connection between innate immunity and nuclear R-loop production which forms a new nucleic acid-based mechanism for cell cycle arrest. This newly identified nucleic acid-based mechanism expands our understanding of viral pathogenesis and may offer potential targets for therapeutic intervention against ZIKV infection and associated neurological complications.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cell cycle, DNA damage, Interferon signaling, R-loop, Zika virus
Hengli Tang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Akash Gunjan, University Representative; Fanxiu Zhu, Committee Member; Yanchang Wang, Committee Member; Darin R. Rokyta, Committee Member.
